{{Infobox football league | logo = Liga BBVA.png | pixels = 200 | country = {{flag|Spain}} | confed = [[UEFA]] | ranking = 2 | founded = 1929 | teams = 20 | relegation = [[Segunda DivisiÃ³n]] | levels = 1 | domest_cup = [[Copa del Rey]] | confed_cup = [[UEFA Champions League]]
[[UEFA Europa League]] | champions = [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] (21st title) | season = [[2010â11 La Liga|2010â11]] | most successful club = [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] (31 titles) | sponsorship_name = Liga BBVA | tv = [[Digital+]], [[Gol TelevisiÃ³n|GolT]], [[laSexta]] | website = [http://www.lfp.es lfp.es] [http://www.facebook.com/lfpoficial facebook.com/lfpoficial] | current = [[2011â12 La Liga|2011â12 season]] }} The '''Primera DivisiÃ³n''' (First Division) of the '''[[Liga de FÃºtbol Profesional|Liga Nacional de FÃºtbol Profesional]] (LFP)''', commonly known as '''La Liga''' (The League) or, for sponsorship reasons, '''Liga BBVA''' ([[BBVA]] League) since 2008, is the top professional [[association football]] division of the [[Spanish football league system]]. It is contested by twenty teams, with the three lowest placed teams [[Promotion and relegation|relegated]] to the [[Segunda DivisiÃ³n]] and replaced by the top three teams in that division. A total of [[La Liga#All-time La Liga table|59 teams]] have competed in La Liga, nine of which have been crowned champions. Since the 1950s, [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] and [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] have dominated the championship. The former have won the title thirty-one times while the latter have won it on twenty-one occasions. However, during the 1930s and 1940s and in the last two decades, La Liga has seen other champions including [[AtlÃ©tico Madrid]], [[Athletic Bilbao]], [[Valencia CF|Valencia]], [[Real Sociedad]], [[Deportivo de La CoruÃ±a|Deportivo]], [[Real Betis]] and [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] . Barcelona have currently won the last three seasons of La Liga. La Liga is currently the second strongest league in Europe according to [[UEFA]]'s [[UEFA coefficient|league coefficient]]. La Liga is one of the most popular professional sports leagues in the world, with an [[List of attendance figures at domestic professional sports leagues|average attendance]] of 28,286 for league matches in the 2009â10 season. This is the sixth highest of any domestic professional sports league in the world and the third highest of any professional [[association football]] league, behind the German [[FuÃball-Bundesliga|Bundesliga]] and English [[Premier League]].{{cite news|url=http://www.european-football-statistics.co.uk/attn.htm|title=European football statistics|year=2008}} ==Competition format== The competition format follows the usual double [[Round-robin tournament|round-robin]] format. During the course of a season, which lasts from September to June, each club plays every other club twice, once at home and once away, for a total of 38 games. Teams receive three points for a win, one point for a draw, and no points for a loss. Teams are ranked by total points, with the highest-ranked club at the end of the season crowned champion. If points are equal between two or more clubs, the rules are{{cite news |title=Reglamento General de la RFEF 2010 (ArtÃ­culo 201) |url=http://www.rfef.es/FCKeditor/UserFiles/File/normativas/Reglamento2010.pdf |publisher=[[Royal Spanish Football Federation|RFEF]] |date=7 June 2010 |accessdate=23 June 2010|language=Spanish}}: *If all clubs involved have played each other twice: **If the tie is between two clubs, then the tie is broken using the head-to-head goal difference (without [[away goals rule]]) **If the tie is between more than two clubs, then the tie is broken, using the games the clubs have played against each other: *** a) head-to-head points *** b) head-to-head goal difference *** c) head-to-head goals scored *If two legged games between all clubs involved have not been played, or the tie is not broken by the rules above, it is broken using: ** a) total goal difference ** b) total goals scored *If the tie is still not broken, the winner will be determined by [[Sportsmanship|Fair Play]] scales.{{cite news |title=Criterios de puntuaciÃ³n del juego limpio |url=http://www.rfef.es/index.jsp?nodo=298#ancla2 |publisher=[[Royal Spanish Football Federation|RFEF]] |date=30 October 1998 |accessdate=18 May 2010|language=Spanish}} These are: ** [[Penalty_card#Yellow_card|yellow card]], 1 point ** [[Penalty_card#Yellow_card|doubled yellow card]]/[[Ejection (sports)|ejection]], 2 points ** [[Penalty_card#Red_card|direct red card]], 3 points ** Suspension or disqualification to [[Head coach|coach]], executive or other club's personnel (outside [[Referee (association football)|referee]] decisions), 5 points ** Misconduct of the [[Fan_(person)#Sports|supporters]]: mild 5 points, serious 6 points, very serious 7 points ** Stadium closure, 10 points ** If the Competition Committee removes a penalty, the points are also removed *If the tie is still not broken, it will be resolved with a tie-break match in a neutral stadium. A system of [[promotion and relegation]] exists between the ''Primera DivisiÃ³n'' and the ''[[Segunda DivisiÃ³n]]''. The three lowest placed teams in La Liga are relegated to the ''Segunda DivisiÃ³n'', and the top two teams from the ''Segunda DivisiÃ³n'' are promoted to La Liga. The third team from the Segunda DivisiÃ³n to be promoted to La Liga is determined by the winner of the play-off played between the winner of the play-off between 3rd against 6th and the winner of the play-off between 4th placed against 5th. These placed teams should be considered excluding reserve teams. ===Qualification for European competitions=== The top teams in La Liga qualify for the [[UEFA Champions League]], with the first, second, and third placed teams directly entering the group stage and the fourth placed team entering the third qualifying round. The fifth and sixth placed teams qualify for the first round of the [[UEFA Europa League]]. ==History== ===Foundation=== In April 1927 Jose Maria Acha, a director at [[Arenas Club de Getxo]], first proposed the idea of a national league in [[Spain]]. After much debate about the size of the league and who would take part, the [[Royal Spanish Football Federation|Real FederaciÃ³n EspaÃ±ola de FÃºtbol]] eventually agreed on the ten teams who would form the first ''Primera DivisiÃ³n'' in [[1929 La Liga|1929]]. [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]], [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]], [[Athletic Bilbao]], [[Real Sociedad]], [[Arenas Club de Getxo]] and [[Real UniÃ³n]] were all selected as previous winners of the [[Copa del Rey]]. [[AtlÃ©tico Madrid]], [[RCD Espanyol|Espanyol]] and [[CE Europa|Europa]] qualified as Copa del Rey runners-up and [[Racing Santander]] qualified through a knockout competition. Only three of the founding clubs, [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]], [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] and [[Athletic Bilbao]], have never been relegated from the ''Primera DivisiÃ³n''. ===The 1930s=== Although [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] won the very first ''Liga'' in [[1929 La Liga|1929]] and [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] won their first titles in [[1931â32 La Liga|1932]] and [[1932â33 La Liga|1933]], it was [[Athletic Bilbao]] that set the early pace winning ''Primera DivisiÃ³n'' in [[1929â30 La Liga|1930]], [[1930â31 La Liga|1931]], [[1933â34 La Liga|1934]] and [[1935â36 La Liga|1936]]. They were also runners-up in [[1931â32 La Liga|1932]] and [[1932â33 La Liga|1933]]. In [[1934â35 La Liga|1935]], [[Real Betis]], then known as ''Betis BalompiÃ©'', won their only title to date. ''Primera DivisiÃ³n'' was suspended during the [[Spanish Civil War]]. In 1937, the teams in the [[Second Spanish Republic|Republican]] area of Spain, with the notable exception of the two [[Madrid]] clubs, competed in the [[Mediterranean League]] and [[FC Barcelona]] emerged as champions. Seventy years later, on 28 September 2007, Barcelona requested [[Royal Spanish Football Federation|RFEF]] to recognise that title as a ''Liga'' title. This action was taken after RFEF recognised [[Levante FC]]'s [[Copa de la EspaÃ±a Libre]] win as equivalent to [[Copa del Rey]] trophy. ===The 1940s=== When the Primera DivisiÃ³n resumed after the [[Spanish Civil War]] it was [[AtlÃ©tico AviaciÃ³n]] (nowadays ''AtlÃ©tico Madrid''), [[Valencia CF|Valencia]] and [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] that initially emerged as the strongest clubs. AtlÃ©tico AviaciÃ³n were only awarded a place during the [[1939â40 La Liga|1939â40]] season as a replacement for [[Real Oviedo]], whose ground had been damaged during the war. The club subsequently won their first Liga title and retained it in [[1940â41 La Liga|1941]]. While other clubs lost players to exile, execution and as casualties of the war, the [[AtlÃ©tico AviaciÃ³n]] team was reinforced by a merger. The young pre-war squad of Valencia had also remained intact and in the post-war years matured into champions, gaining three Liga titles in [[1941â42 La Liga|1942]], [[1943â44 La Liga|1944]] and [[1946â47 La Liga|1947]]. They were also runners-up in [[1947â48 La Liga|1948]] and [[1948â49 La Liga|1949]]. Sevilla also enjoyed a brief golden era, finishing as runners-up in [[1939â40 La Liga|1940]] and [[1941â42 La Liga|1942]] before winning their only title to date in [[La Liga 1945â46|1946]]. By the latter part of the decade [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] began to emerge as a force when they were crowned champions in [[1944â45 La Liga|1945]], [[1947â48 La Liga|1948]] and [[1948â49 La Liga|1949]]. ===Di StÃ©fano, PuskÃ¡s, Kubala and SuÃ¡rez=== Although [[AtlÃ©tico Madrid]], previously known as ''AtlÃ©tico AviaciÃ³n'', were champions in 1950 and 1951 under ''[[catenaccio]]'' mastermind [[Helenio Herrera]], the 1950s saw the beginning of the [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]]/[[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] dominance. During the 1930s, 1940s and 1950s there were strict limits imposed on foreign players. In most cases clubs could only have three foreign players in their squads, meaning that at least eight local players had to play in every game. During the 1950s, however, these rules were circumvented by [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] and [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] who naturalized [[Alfredo di StÃ©fano]], [[Ferenc PuskÃ¡s]] and [[Ladislav Kubala]]. Inspired by Kubala, BarÃ§a won the title in 1952 and 1953. Di StÃ©fano, PuskÃ¡s and [[Francisco Gento]] formed the nucleus of the [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] team that dominated the second half of the 1950s. Madrid won the first division for the first time as Real Madrid in 1954 and retained its title in 1955. They were winners again in 1957 and 1958, with only [[Athletic Bilbao]] interrupting their sequence. During this period, Real Madrid also won an unprecedented five consecutive European Cups. [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] with a team coached by [[Helenio Herrera]] and featuring [[Luis SuÃ¡rez Miramontes|Luis SuÃ¡rez]] gained the title in 1959 and 1960. ===The Madrid years=== Between 1961 and 1980, [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] dominated the ''Primera DivisiÃ³n'' being crowned champion 14 times. This included a five-in-a-row sequence from 1961 to 1965 and two three-in-a-row sequences (1967â1969 and 1978â1980). During this era only [[AtlÃ©tico Madrid]] offered Real Madrid any serious challenge, adding four more titles to their tally in 1966, 1970, 1973 and 1977. Of the other clubs, only [[Valencia CF|Valencia]] in 1971 and the [[Johan Cruyff]]-inspired [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] of 1974 managed to break the dominance of Real Madrid. ===The 1980s=== The [[Madrid]] winning sequence was ended more significantly in 1981 when [[Real Sociedad]] won their first ever title. They retained it in 1982 and their two in a row was followed by another by their fellow [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basques]], [[Athletic Bilbao]] who won back-to-back titles in 1983 and 1984. [[Terry Venables]] led [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] to a solitary title in 1985 before [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] won again another five in a row sequence (1986â1990) with a team, guided by [[Leo Beenhakker]], and including [[Hugo SÃ¡nchez]] and the legendary [[Quinta del Buitre|''La Quinta del Buitre'']] - [[Emilio ButragueÃ±o]], [[Manuel SanchÃ­s Hontiyuelo|Manolo SanchÃ­s]], [[Rafael MartÃ­n VÃ¡zquez|MartÃ­n VÃ¡zquez]], [[JosÃ© Miguel GonzÃ¡lez MartÃ­n|MÃ­chel]] and [[Miguel Pardeza Pichardo|Miguel Pardeza]]. ===The 1990s=== [[Johan Cruyff]] returned to [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] as manager in 1988, and assembled the legendary ''Dream Team''. Cruyff introduced players like [[Josep Guardiola]], [[JosÃ© Mari Bakero]], [[Aitor Beguiristain|Txiki Beguiristain]], [[Jon Andoni Goikoetxea LasÃ¡|Goikoetxea]], [[Ronald Koeman]], [[Michael Laudrup]], [[RomÃ¡rio]] and [[Hristo Stoichkov]]. This team won ''Primera DivisiÃ³n'' four times between 1991 and 1994 and won the [[European Cup 1991-92|European Cup]] in 1992. Laudrup then moved to arch-rivals [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] after a fall-out with Cruyff, and helped them end Barcelona's run in 1995. [[AtlÃ©tico Madrid]] won their ninth ''Primera DivisiÃ³n'' title in 1996 before Real Madrid added another Liga trophy to their cabinet in 1997. After the success of Cruyff, another Dutchman - Ajax manager [[Louis van Gaal]] - arrived at the [[Camp Nou]], and with the talents of [[LuÃ­s Figo]], [[LuÃ­s Enrique MartÃ­nez GarcÃ­a|Luis Enrique]] and [[Rivaldo]], Barcelona again won the title in 1998 and 1999. Meanwhile, Real Madrid also experienced success on the continental stage, winning the [[UEFA Champions League]] in 1998. ===The 2000s=== As ''Primera DivisiÃ³n'' entered a new century, the Big Two found themselves facing new challengers. Between 1993 and 2004, [[Deportivo de La CoruÃ±a|Deportivo La CoruÃ±a]] finished in the top three on ten occasions, a better record than either [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] or [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]], and in 2000, under [[Javier Irureta]], they became the ninth team to be crowned champions. Real Madrid won two more Liga titles in 2001 and 2003 and also the [[UEFA Champions League]] in 2000 and 2002, and won their third league title in 2007 after a three year drought. They were challenged by a re-emerging [[Valencia CF|Valencia]] in both competitions. Under the management of [[HÃ©ctor CÃºper]], Valencia finished as Champions League runners-up in 2000 and 2001. His successor, [[Rafael BenÃ­tez]], built on this and led the club to a Liga title in 2002 and the winning a double with a league title and the [[2003â04 UEFA Cup|UEFA Cup]] in 2004. The 2004â05 season saw a resurgent Barcelona, inspired by the brilliant [[Ronaldinho]], win their first title of the new century, in addition to the Liga-Champions League double in 2005â06. Real Madrid won La Liga in 2006â07 and 2007â08 season. ===The Barcelona Years=== Barcelona won the league in 2009, as part of their [[The Treble|treble]] winning season. On 20 May 2010, a study published by the University of Barcelona revealed that La Liga's debt had risen to â¬3.53 billion.http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=788913&sec=europe&cc=5901 There were only three clubs in the all divisions (Barcelona, Real Madrid, and Numancia) who had an operating profit. The study further revealed that 85% of club debt was accumulated from player wages. The debt crisis in La Liga and Spain as a whole has led to summits held by the presidents of each club, the goal being to renegotiate the Madrid and Barcelona dominated television rights, opting for a voting-bloc system much like the [[Premier League]]. Barcelona won the title in 2010 and again in 2011 as part of a Liga-Champions League double. == Teams == [[Deportivo La CoruÃ±a]], [[HÃ©rcules CF]] from [[Alicante]] and [[UD AlmerÃ­a]] were relegated to the [[2011â12 Segunda DivisiÃ³n]] after finishing in the bottom three spots of the table at the end of the [[2010â11 La Liga|2010â11 season]]. Deportivo were relegated to the Segunda DivisiÃ³n after twenty seasons of continuous membership in the top football league of Spain, while AlmerÃ­a ended a four-year tenure in La Liga and HÃ©rcules made their immediate return to the second level. The three relegated teams were replaced by three [[2010â11 Segunda DivisiÃ³n]] sides. Champions [[Real Betis|Betis]], who terminated their second-level status after two years, runners-up [[Rayo Vallecano]], who returned to the top flight after eight seasons at lower levels, earned direct promotion. The third promoted team was decided in the [[2010â11 La Liga Play-Off|promotion play-offs]] where [[Granada CF|Granada]] returned to the league for the first time in 35 years, having spent 26 of them in [[Segunda DivisiÃ³n B]] and [[Tercera DivisiÃ³n]]. ===Stadia and locations=== {{Location map+ |Spain |width=400 |float=right |caption=Location of (qualified) teams in La Liga 2011â12 Madrigal]] | 25,000 |- | [[Real Zaragoza|Zaragoza]] | [[Zaragoza]] | [[La Romareda]] | 34,596 |} {{clear}} ==La Liga clubs in Europe== {{Main|La Liga clubs in Europe}} In addition to their success in Primera DivisiÃ³n, Real Madrid, Barcelona, [[AtlÃ©tico de Madrid]] and Valencia are four of the most successful teams in [[European football records|European competition history]]. All four clubs are the only [[Spain|Spanish]] clubs to have won 5 or more [[international]] trophies. All four clubs are also in the top ten most successful clubs in European football in terms of total European trophies.{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/printoutfiles/competitions/supercup/2006/e/e_84343_pk.pdf|title=UEFA club competitions press kit (.PDF archive, page 23)|accessdate=2006-08-25|publisher=UEFA Official Website}} In 2005â06, [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] won the [[2005â06 UEFA Champions League|UEFA Champions League]] and [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] won the [[2005â06 UEFA Cup|UEFA Cup]]. The ''Primera DivisiÃ³n'' became the first league to do the European "double" since 1997. The Primera DivisiÃ³n is currently second in the [[UEFA coefficients|UEFA rankings]] of European leagues based on their performances in European competitions over a five-year period, behind the English [[Premier League]] in first and ahead of Germany's [[FuÃball-Bundesliga|Bundesliga]] in third.{{cite news|url=http://www.xs4all.nl/~kassiesa/bert/uefa/data/method4/crank2011.html|title=UEFA ranking of European leagues|publisher=Bert Kassies|date=May 2011}} ==Champions== {{Main|List of Spanish football champions}} ===Performance by club=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! width=15%| Club ! || - || - || [[1955â56 La Liga|1955â56]] || [[1955â56 La Liga|1955â56]] || 15 |- align="center" |} League or status at [[2011â12 in Spanish football|2011â12]]: {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; font-size:95%;" |- |width=10px bgcolor=ACE1AF| ||[[2011â12 La Liga]] |- |width=10px bgcolor=FBE08D| ||[[2011â12 Segunda DivisiÃ³n]] |- |width=10px bgcolor=EBC9FE| ||[[2011â12 Segunda DivisiÃ³n B]] |- |width=10px bgcolor=C1DDFD| ||[[2011â12 Tercera DivisiÃ³n]] |- |width=10px bgcolor=FFFDDF| ||[[Divisiones Regionales de FÃºtbol|2011â12 Divisiones Regionales]] |- |width=10px bgcolor=FFFFFF| ||To be determined |- |width=10px bgcolor=FCFF13| ||No longer affiliated with [[Royal Spanish Football Federation|RFEF]] |- |width=10px bgcolor=BBBBBB| ||Club disappeared |} ==Players== ===Eligibility of non-EU players=== In La Liga, players can claim citizenship from the nation their ancestors came from. If a player does not have European ancestry, he can claim Spanish citizenship after playing in Spain for 5 years.{{Citation needed|date=February 2009}} Sometimes, this can lead to a triple-citizenship situation e.g. [[Leo Franco]], who is Argentine-born, of Italian heritage and can claim a Spanish passport, having played in La Liga for over 5 years.{{Dubious|date=July 2009}} In addition, players from the [[ACP countries]]âcountries in [[Africa]], the [[Caribbean]], and the [[Oceania|Pacific]] that are signatories to the [[Cotonou Agreement]]âare not counted against non-EU quotas, due to the [[Kolpak ruling]]. ===Individual awards=== Until season 2008/2009 no official awards for la liga existed. Following the 2008/2009 season LFP the governing body instated the [[LFP Awards]], apart from these awards, many individual awards are conceded relating to La Liga, although not sanctioned by the [[Liga de FÃºtbol Profesional|LFP]] nor the [[Royal Spanish Football Federation|RFEF]] and therefore not regarded as official. The most notable of these are four awarded by Spain's biggest sports paper, ''[[Diario Marca|Marca]]'', namely the [[Pichichi Trophy]], awarded to the top scorer of the season, the [[Ricardo Zamora Trophy]] for the goalkeeper with the least "goals-to-games" ratio, the [[Trofeo Alfredo di StÃ©fano]], for the player judged to be the best overall player in the division, and the [[Zarra Trophy]] is awarded to the Spanish domestic player with the highest goal total in La Liga. ===All-time top scorers=== {|border=1 cellpadding=2 class="wikitable sortable" !Rank !width=50|Nat !width=150|Name
